review_title: Amazing people, amazing cause, amazing employer
job_title: Membership Venues Officer in North Yorkshire, England
pros: The RSPB is by a country mile the best employer I’ve ever had and I still feel like I’m living the dream. The salary is far higher than I would expect and I feel valued, recognised, supported and encouraged. I am immensely proud to work for an organisation that cares so much for its people as well as for nature. Yes of course we are all just human and don’t always get it right, but the difference is the RSPB are constantly looking for ways to make it better and make it a welcoming, diverse, happy and inclusive workplace. I feel this message is very well cascaded down to management. Being in the RSPB is like being in a family - we may sometimes have our issues but at the end of the day we all love each other and we are all here for the bigger picture. Thank you, RSPB, for making my career to date such a happy one and I hope you’ll put up with me for a long time yet.
cons: Some days are stressful and you can have a high workload at times, but the management are there to support you, as are your colleagues, so communicate and ask for help and you will get it. You can end up being your own worst enemy because you want to work hard and give 150% for the cause, so you end up working very long hours and taking on extra work and responsibilities out of a genuine desire to give your all to something you’re so passionate about, but you have to learn to take a step back sometimes and say no otherwise you risk burnout, and that’s something I’m still trying to learn to do. Career opportunities are not always plentiful, but then again what can you expect- we are a charity and only have so many positions and financial resource. If you really want to progress, you may have to wait a bit longer than you’d like, but the opportunities do come around, it just requires a bit of patience!

review_title: Useful career start but not middle: RSPB Royal Society for the Protection of Birds Ornithology
pros:
Useful job to start a career in the environment/ecology sector but the pay will never get you anywhere (car/mortgage) in life unless you have other financial work options or you are very senior management (big pay range between the workers and generals!). 
Field research jobs can be refreshing working from nice reserves and hands on experience with birds, where you can see the annual results of breeding success.
cons:
Note: in line with other reviews staff or not supported (financially, expenses, benefits, job praise, HR) very well.
Staff are expected to go above and beyond with working hours with no real toil/overtime leading to stress and moving on to better paid consultancies as a rights of passage. 
Poorly paid compared to other ecologist jobs. 
Volunteers are used more increasingly to fill in for seasonal research assistant staff which has knock on effects in terms of quality of data.
Management poorly trained, most have no knowledge of business. 
Staff not accountable for timesheets, therefore lots of time wasted through tea and cake breaks and early Fridays. 
Some senior staff appear to be jaded and cynical. 
The organisation although a charity is using a corporate type of image and is less like it used to be. 
Interestingly you have to be prepared to face some abuse from farmers and landowners. 
Some jobs have been lined up for internal staff therefore 'jobs for the boys' unfortunately is present within the RSPB.

pros: - nice grounds to walk around in
cons:
RSPB really is not a great place to work. RSPB is facing great financial difficulties and employees are not being replaced when they leave. There is incredibly low morale.
- Poor pay, with no chance of progression even when completing work to a high standard, taking on additional work, and having been there for a number of years.
- Little to no training for your role, but still the expectation that you will 'hit the ground running'.
- No opportunity to progress into different roles, despite an ongoing restructure and a huge number of people leaving and not being replaced. Administrator's are made to take on the work of a fellow administrator when they leave, therefore putting those who remain under increasing pressure (but still no chance of receiving a pay increase to reflect this additional workload).
- Antiquated systems. Laptops that were purchased from the early 2000s still in use despite being incredibly slow. Software systems are chosen based on cost rather than efficiency.
- A large proportion of RSPB employees love nothing more than writing incredibly long emails to each other (rather than talking) and creating incredibly long documents. Staff will often spend a large proportion of their time rewriting or extensively editing documents that I question ever see the light of day, let alone have any impact on the cause. 
- RSPB cannot cope with change. There are a number of RSPB employees that have worked there for 25+ years and this has made RSPB very institutionalised with a 'we do it this way because we have always done it this way' attitude.

review_title: Good and ethical employer, with problems just like all employers have
pros:
Great charitable goals working with dedicated people and always learning about issues, species and the problems actions of yesteryear have created. Very ethical and fair employer for the most part, although time in lieu can be dependent on your manager. 

Some great work going on with schools and children, not to mention some cutting edge science, particularly with seabirds, which determines what they do. Also, the wildlife crime team are fantastic. 

All the training you need is provided and this is also a good way to meet colleagues who you find are always willing to give you help and advice when needed.

I must say that - to me - in spite of it not knowing who it is - grassroots charity v corporate image - it is very ambitious and it is hard to fault that. 

Volunteers!! The best part of my role was meeting and working with the amazing teams that freely give so much time to helping nature.
cons:
Excessively process oriented in some areas, and I think this could also be as a result of constant promotions from within and not much new blood coming in. As a charity, however, it is important to retain people you have already invested time and costs training in. I do feel, that said, this needs to be remedied as for some people, I did not understand why they were in the roles they were in. 

Membership targets seem to have a bit of unevenness/unfairness depending on where you are. Additionally, as a membership salesperson and thus brand ambassador, you are only measured on memberships made, and not all the smiles and good experiences you give people. That I admit, is hard to avoid.  I did notice a lot of turnover in the MDO roles in my last 8 months or so, which possibly shows something may not be right. 

The reserve I worked at in my last year was struggling for new footfall, and even though our memberships made to non-member visitor ratio was great, it always felt like we were getting the knife stuck in. Again, hard times for charities so the pressure was on for everyone, but this did not help anyone. The reserve needed to evolve and get some investment put in, and hopefully that happens in the future. 

The pay issue needs to be mentioned as it has been brought up repeatedly by others. The charity can't just pay market level wages because the projects need the money. Most people realise this and are dedicated enough to the cause to accept that. However, MDOs are not paid enough and there is no financial incentive apart from a discretionary £500 bonus which is halved after tax anyhow. I was lucky to get it one year however many aren't, and paying MDOs - the face of the RSPB and a large source of income - £17,200 is not enough for the effort put in and stress endured.

review_title: RSPB Fundraising Direct - poor pay, lone working, depressing
job_title: RSPB Fundraising Direct in Leeds, England
pros:
Easy to get the job, think they would take anyone who's interested
Not early mornings - normal weekday is 11-6 (although this varies)
Worthwhile cause
cons:
- Despite the job description being confusing, this IS street fundraising!!
- They expect you to work an additional hour after you get home for "admin", which means very long days...only 30mins unpaid break each day
-Generally outside all the time, which is even expected in terrible weather conditions (rain/high winds/snow)
- Fundraising targets are unrealistic, I worked in the "top team in the country" and the team had on average been below target members for the past 3 months.....this means that the promise of pay rise /& commission is pretty hard to achieve. Also when working with 2 people on the stall targets are expected to be the same, even though footfall/the number of people interested isn't going to automatically double when there are 2 of you fundraising!
- They expect you to pump a significant amount of time/money into making your stall look good - "this pays off if it gets you more members" they say!Realistically though this doesn't really work and you are not paid for any over-time you spend doing this.
- VERY hard to actually attract members when the membership doesn't actually include anything you can "sell", except a magazine...which a lot of people don't want anyway
-You are made to feel guilty about not getting members because it is a charity, constantly getting texts about other team members who are doing well which isn't motivating!
- Long drives to different locations each day, average is 45mins according to management, but is longer than this a lot of the time.
-Working alone a lot of the time, even though when I asked about this at interview I was told 3/5 days would be with someone else and in the first 2 months not alone at all. I was alone 2/5 days in my first week, which was very difficult.
-Expected to work EVERY Saturday and most bank holidays (which again isn't clear at application stage, which says "some/occasional weekends")
-VERY high drop out rate in the first couple of months

-A general conclusion: this is the hardest job I've done, with very poor rewards when you are expected to give your life and soul to raise memberships. Genuinely bad for mental health, wouldn't wish this job on my worst enemy. Job description and what you get told at interview isn't an honest picture of what its really like, you only start to see a more realistic view at training and once you start - which leads you to feel like they've purposely deceived you!

So disappointed by this job because I wanted to feel like I was helping the conservation efforts and it is a good British charity with some great values but treats employees like throw-away garbage.
